# Sharing code

--

### - It's about keeping track of different versions of the code

--

### - Developers have been doing this for decades now

--

### - They have created great tools for this

--

### - `r gt()` is (probably) the most popular

--

### - `r gh()` is the largest host for `r gt()` repositories



---
# `r gt()` in a nutshell 


### - `r gt()` is a fully distributed version control system

--

### - `r gt()` was originally developed by developers of the Linux kernel to [develop the kernel](https://github.com/torvalds/linux)

--

### - 01/06 v1.0; 05/14 ve2.0; 01/22 [v2.35](https://github.blog/2022-01-24-highlights-from-git-2-35/)

### - 2005 Linux Kernel developers needed a new tool to replace [BitKeeper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitKeeper)


---
# `r gt()` in a nutshell 

### - `r gt()` is fast and allow for non-linear develop via a killer branching system.

--

### - `r gt()` creates snapshots of a file system ("commits") stored in a local database `.git` that can be shared.
